name.description: 1822-1910. Born at Norway House, daughter of HBC factor; spent girlhood at Cumberland House; became second wife of Rev. James Hunter, 1848; translated parts of the Bible, prayers, and hymns into Cree; Pilling, who corresponded with her, gives her name as Jean and her birthdate as July 26, 1822; Rev. J. Smithurst, who officiated at her wedding, referred to her as Jane (Letters of Letitia Hargrave; Pilling, Bibliography of the Algonquian languages).

1842-1917. Son of Rev. G.M. McDougall; to the West, 1860; taught school at Norway House; entered Methodist ministry, 1866, and ordained, 1874; for many years served in Alberta, first at Victoria, and later at Morley (Morgan, Canadian men and women of the time, 1912).

1852-1927. Methodist clergyman, ordained, 1887; spent 7 years at Battle River, 9 at Whitefish Lake on Indian missionary work; stationed at Snowflake, Manitoba, 1902 (Riddell, Methodism in the middle west; United Church of Canada yearbook, 1930).

name.description: 1890-1932. Formerly thought to have been born on the Blood Indian reserve in southern Alberta; spent much of his life in USA where he attained considerable popularity as a lecturer; actually, born Sylvester Long in North Carolina to parents of mixed ancestry, possibly black and white or Native and white; committed suicide when imposture revealed; see Donald B. Smith, Long Lance: The true story of an impostor (Toronto: Macmillan of Canada, 1982), and Chief Buffalo Child Long Lance: The glorious impostor (Red Deer, Alta.: Red Deer Press, 1999).

name.description: d.1962. Born in Sydenham, Ontario, probably mid-1870s; father a Methodist minister; studied briefly at Victoria University in Toronto; early in 20th century proprietor and editor of Medicine Hat Times for about 3 years; travelled and lived in England in early 1920s, Florida in early 1930s, Toronto in early 1940s, and California in 1950s; prolific writer of genre fiction; used pseudonyms Luke Allan and Lacey Amy (Walden, Journal of Canadian Studies, vol.24, no.2, Summer).

name.description: 1832-1900. From England to Canada, 1862; to Red River, 1866; became involved in local politics, and instrumental in calling a meeting favouring union with Canada; later a prime mover in sending an invitation to the Prince of Wales from the First Nations asking him to visit; settled in Portage la Prairie, 1867; organized a provisional government, Republic of Manitoba, with himself as president, but government soon collapsed; edited The New Nation,1870; after formation of the province of Manitoba, became clerk of Legislative Council, and later of Legislative Assembly; census commissioner for NWT in 1881 and 1885; lived in California for some years engaged in immigration work; assistant registrar in Dominion land office in Edmonton, 1895-1900 (Edmonton Bulletin, March 23, 1900; Robertson, A political manual of the province of Manitoba).
